STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 27, 2025
Stacy Houghtaling
Clinton/Eaton County DHHS
1050 INDEPENDENCE BLVD,
CHARLOTTE, MI, 48813-1032
RE: License#: CP230201103
Dear Stacy Houghtaling:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT

children in foster home, Supervise

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
One of Six open foster home files reviewed contained a renewal inspection report
with a recommendation that was not made to the department at least 15 days
prior to the license expiring.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal 10/02/2023, CAP Approved 10/16/2023
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (d) A copy of all special evaluations
completed during the last 2 years.

One of Three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain documentation of
courtesy assignment to the record prior to placement in order to view special
evaluation reports completed over the past 2 years.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim12/20/2024, CAP Approved 1/06/2024
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (a) Approval from the certifying agency
authorizing the placement of a child in the
home.
One of Three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain documentation of
approval from the loaning agency.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim12/20/2024, CAP Approved 1/06/2024
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (b) Verification that the foster parent is
willing to accept the foster child.
One of Three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain documentation of the
foster parent's willingness to accept youth from borrowing agency.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim12/20/2024, CAP Approved 1/06/2024

CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (e) Verification of all children currently
placed in the home.
One of Three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain documentation of
courtesy assignment to the record prior to placement in order to view/update
placement record.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim12/20/2024, CAP Approved 1/06/2024
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (f) Documentation that the foster parent
has received orientation to the policies of
the borrowing agency.
One of Three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain documentation the
foster parent was provided orientation to borrowing agency policies prior to
placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim12/20/2024, CAP Approved 1/06/2024
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:

• (g) A copy of the foster parent /agency
agreement signed by the foster parent
and the borrowing agency.
One of Three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain foster parent/agency
agreement signed prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim12/20/2024, CAP Approved 1/06/2024
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (c) The initial evaluation and current
reevaluation.
One of Three borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain documentation of
courtesy assignment to the record prior to placement in order to view all initial and
reevaluation reports prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim12/20/2024, CAP Approved 1/06/2024
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (e) A dental examination must be
completed within 3 months before entry
into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more
than 90 calendar days after entry into a
foster care out-of-home placement. A
child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam
within 3 months of his or her first birthday.
One of Six open files of youth in foster care placement reviewed did not a contain
an initial dental examination completed within the required timeframe.

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (2) For an emergency placement, if any of the
information specified in subrule (1)(a) to (h) of
this rule is not available at the time of
placement, then the agency shall provide
information to the foster parent within 7 calendar
days of the placement.
One of Six open files of youth in foster care placement reviewed did not contain
documentation of all required information provided to caregiver within 7 days of
emergency placement. The form on which the information is typically documented
(DHS-3307) was present in the file but the majority of fields did not contain
information.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or
parents and the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting
the agency in carrying out the plan. An agency
shall give a copy to and review the parent-
agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the
parent or parents and foster parent that the
information in the parent-agency treatment plan
and any other information about the child and
the child's family is confidential.
Two of Six open files of youth in foster care placement reviewed did not contain
documentation that all PATPs were provided to and discussed with the parents
and/or foster parents.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
• (2) An agency social service worker shall visit
the foster child, and the foster parent, if
applicable, in the child's placement at least once
every month.

Two of Six open files of youth in foster care placement reviewed did not contain
documentation that all monthly visits with youths and foster parents were
completed as required. One case was missing a visit within the month the youth
was removed from the home. One file contained visits in the foster home with the
youth for three consecutive months; however the worker did not visit with the
foster parents. The foster father was present for two of those three visits, but the
worker documented he was unavailable to meet. No foster parents were present
for the third visit.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical Assistance was provided regarding the wording in one special
evaluation report regarding a pool not having sufficient barriers as explanation
was needed as to what was meant by the pool not being in use. Be sure to
include details if a pool without proper barriers is emptied and cannot be
accessed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• No consultation was requested or required.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The one
CAP submitted by the agency during the period under review was submitted in
response to the 2024 licensing inspection report dated 9/18/2024. That CAP was
approved on 10/10/2024 and addressed eleven violations; two of which were
policy violations no longer regulated by DCWL. Of the remaining nine violations
addressed in that CAP, seven were related to borrowed bed requirements, all of
which were repeated during this investigation and require assessment and
additional corrective action planning. The two violations addressed in that CAP not
repeated during this inspection were related to foster home special evaluation
requirements.
During the period under review the Child Placing Agency license was closed for
the Clinton County office and that office became a satellite to the Eaton County
office. This has some impact on the comparison between the 2024 and 2025
inspections as the 2024 inspection and CAP for the Clinton County files are not
represented.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment dated 6/23/2025 was reviewed and discussed
during the entrance meeting. The chief administrator identified the largest barrier
to adhering to statute, administrative rules, ISEP, and policy during the past year
has been the placement crisis for older and more difficult to place youth. She
indicates the exhaustive placement efforts are time consuming and negatively
impact a worker's ability to complete other required tasks timely. Additionally, the
chief administrator indicated the required tasks and responsibilities continue to
increase while caseloads are not reduced resulting in difficulty maintaining
compliance with all requirements. The chief administrator documented frustration
with the licensing standard of 100% compliance as that expectation does not
account for situations outside of a worker's control while other department
programs are held to a 95% compliance standard by their regulatory bodies. The
chief administrator reported the 2024 corrective action plan was largely effective
and tasks put into place of helped maintain compliance as well as to identify
barriers resulting in problem solving discussions.
Financial Overview
N/A

Staff Interviews
The staff members interviewed reported enjoying working for the county offices
stating they get good support from management. They stated they participate in
weekly meetings during which any changes/updates to case management
expectations are reviewed. The staff members reported their caseloads are
manageable overall and stated there is always someone at the agency willing to
help, when needed. The staff members did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency office has adequate space and equipment for the delivery of foster
care, independent living, and certification services. Physical CHRI is stored
securely within locked drawers in a licensing worker's cubicle and multiple cross
shredders are in the office. Closed adoption files are locked in cabinets which are
located in the main office.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
June 26, 2025
_____________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 27, 2025
_____________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
